entry.title: “让‘社交’再次社交”——埃夫·威廉姆斯解释墨子
entry.content:
埃夫·威廉姆斯 (Ev Williams) 撰写了《墨子》的背景故事和存在理由：

20 多年后，我们的地址簿中充满了部分、重复和过时的信息。也许原因是社交网络（或社交网络）暂时解决了这个问题。当 Facebook 无处不在时，它可能很好地反映了许多人的现实生活关系。它告诉你他们住在哪里，你认识谁，以及各种其他细节。

另一个似乎显而易见的想法是，鉴于人类的社交程度有多深，社交产品将主导互联网。十到十五年前，这似乎是不可避免的。

但相反发生了其他事情。

社交网络变成了“社交媒体”，最初意味着从你选择的人那里接收内容。但为了最大限度地提高参与度，你选择关注的朋友和人的时间线变成了一场争夺注意力的混战。事实证明，对于大多数人来说，你的朋友并不像有影响力的人那样有趣（上帝禁止）那些在醒着的时候制作“内容”的人。

换句话说，社交媒体变成了……媒体。

说实话，我认为这种演变有积极的方面（也许我会在另一篇文章中讨论这一点）。但我们显然失去了一些东西。

整个片子写得很好，很清晰。事后看来，社交网络和社交媒体之间的这种区别是显而易见的，但也只是事后看来。 Williams 将其发布在 Medium 上（当然），但Mozi 的网站直接链接到其“关于”页面。我对此感到很兴奋。我认为他们在这里有所作为。这甚至是一个伟大的名字。

★

entry.title: 墨子
entry.content:
由 Ev Williams 牵头的新应用程序：

Mozi 是一个私人社交网络，可以让您在现实生活中更多地见到您的朋友。添加您的计划，查看谁在城里，并了解您何时重叠。

目前仅限 iOS，“使用 Apple 登录”是唯一支持的身份验证方法。一个聪明的想法是，你可以分享旅行计划和你的位置，当你可能与朋友在同一地区时，Mozi 会进行协调。从他们的常见问题解答中：

为什么您需要访问我的联系人？你会联系我电话簿里的人吗？

绝不。我们要求访问您的联系人，以便您可以与您在 Mozi 上认识的人联系。为了在 Mozi 上看到某人，你们必须都在 Mozi 上并且彼此都保存为 iOS 联系人。我们绝不会发送、出售或分享您的任何信息，也绝不会代表您联系您的人员。我们不存储任何实际的电话号码，而是对它们进行哈希（加密）。这可确保您的号码和所有联系人保持匿名并受到保护。

我加入了，到目前为止只有三个互助。但是——他们三个都是我真正喜欢面对面陪伴的人。正确的是，我们都对想要我们个人信息的新“社交”平台保持警惕，但我们集体变得如此愤世嫉俗，以至于我担心人们甚至不想尝试像 Mozi 这样有趣的新事物。埃夫·威廉姆斯（Ev Williams）拥有独特的优势，能够以值得信赖的方式让这样的事情发生。

我主要支持墨子的成功，因为我认为这样的事情可以以一种只有优点的方式发挥作用，而今天没有什么比这更好的了。但我也支持 Mozi 的成功，只是为了 戳破凯文·罗斯 (Kevin Roose) 10 月在《纽约时报》上发表的文章的荒谬之处，该文章试图证明苹果通过增加对 iOS 联系人的隐私控制来“杀死社交应用程序”。根据团队的记录和上面引用的常见问题解答，我很高兴与 Mozi 分享了我的整个联系人列表。

谈到《纽约时报》，艾琳·格里菲斯 (Erin Griffith) 为 Mozi 的推出写了一篇威廉姆斯的简介：

“互联网确实让我们的联系更加紧密，”他在加利福尼亚州门洛帕克接受采访时表示，“但它也让我们更加分裂。它让我们拥有了更多的一切。”

墨子本来就是一个实用工具。如果用户想在应用程序中向朋友发送消息以制定计划，应用程序会将他们引导至手机的短信应用程序。

★

entry.title: 神奇的克雷斯金去世，享年 89 岁
entry.content:
纽约时报：

乔治·J·克雷斯吉 (George J. Kresge) 周二在新泽西州韦恩去世，享年 89 岁。 乔治·J·克雷斯吉 (George J. Kresge) 是一位名叫《神奇克雷斯金》(Amazing Kreskin) 的艺人，他在 20 世纪 70 年代的深夜电视上成名，他利用心灵魔术让观众眼花缭乱。他于周二在新泽西州韦恩去世，享年 89 岁。说死者是在辅助生活设施中死于痴呆症并发症。

克雷斯金的壮举包括预测陌生人个人生活的细节以及猜测从一副牌中随机选择的扑克牌。他在现场表演中有一个经典的伎俩：委托观众把他的薪水藏在礼堂里，然后依靠自己的直觉找到它——否则一晚就没有报酬。

不知何故，他直到 1990 年才第一次与莱特曼合作，但在那之后他就成为了常客。简直就是那个时代典型的“深夜脱口秀嘉宾”。他擅长心灵魔术，但克雷斯金之所以伟大，甚至令人惊奇，是因为他是一个如此奇怪、有趣和有趣的人。

★

entry.summary: The Information 的报道表明，Ultra 之上的 M 系列可能还需要数年时间。
entry.content:
马韦恩 (Wayne Ma) 和刘倩儿 (Qianer Liu) 在今天为 The Information 发表的一篇文章中（遗憾的是，付费墙已经满了），“苹果正在与博通合作开发人工智能芯片”：

据三位直接了解该项目的人士透露，苹果正在开发首款专为人工智能设计的服务器芯片，因为这家 iPhone 制造商准备应对其新人工智能功能的强烈计算需求。一位知情人士表示，苹果正在与博通合作开发该芯片的网络技术，这对于人工智能处理至关重要。如果苹果公司的 AI 芯片（内部代号为 Baltra，预计将于 2026 年实现量产）取得成功，这将标志着该公司芯片团队的一个重要里程碑。 [...]

博通通常不会许可其知识产权，而是选择直接向客户销售芯片。例如，在与谷歌的协议中，博通将谷歌的人工智能芯片蓝图转化为可以制造的设计，与台积电一起监督其生产，并将成品芯片加价出售给谷歌。

但博通似乎对苹果采取了不同的策略。其中一位知情人士表示，博通正在向苹果提供范围更为有限的设计服务，同时仍向这家 iPhone 制造商提供其网络技术。另一位人士表示，苹果仍在管理该芯片的生产，而台积电将负责该生产。无法了解业务安排的其他细节[原文如此] 1

我敢断言，苹果选择对博通采取与谷歌不同的策略，而不是博通推动的任何选择。上述信息自己的“与谷歌的安排”链接指向今年前的报告，该报告开篇称：“据一位直接了解相关情况的人士透露，谷歌高管已广泛讨论最早在 2027 年放弃博通作为人工智能芯片供应商的可能性。” 。这位人士表示，在这种情况下，谷歌将在内部完全设计​​这些芯片，即张量处理单元。此举可以帮助谷歌每年节省数十亿美元的成本，因为它在人工智能开发上投入巨资，与其他类型的计算相比，人工智能开发的成本尤其昂贵。”为什么苹果会同意这样的安排呢？

对博通的谄媚暗示在我看来，很明显，是博通的消息来源为这个故事提供了泄密信息。

无论如何，这份报告中真正引起我注意的不是人工智能服务器芯片，而是以下内容（强调了添加的关键段落），尽管​​我认为它是报告中最有趣的金块，但似乎只是作为旁白包含在内（费马大定理的模糊阴影）：

两位知情人士表示，苹果位于以色列的芯片设计团队正在主导人工智能芯片的开发。该团队在设计 Apple 于 2020 年推出的处理器以取代 Mac 中的英特尔芯片方面发挥了重要作用。

一位知情人士表示，去年夏天，苹果公司取消了 Mac 高性能芯片（由四个较小的芯片拼接在一起）的开发，以腾出以色列的一些工程师来开发人工智能芯片，这突显了该公司的转变优先事项。

三位知情人士表示，为了制造这款芯片，苹果计划使用台积电最先进的制造工艺之一，即 N3P。这将是对苹果最新计算机处理器 M4 制造工艺的改进。

他们所说的关于取消的高端 Mac 芯片将是一个假设的 M 系列芯片，其规格（实际上）是 Ultra 的两倍，我认为它只会在未来的 Mac Pro 中提供，并且，只是拉从苹果营销词典中的形容词来看，我敢打赌会被称为“M# Extreme”（其中“#”是 M 系列的代号）。 M1 和 M2 Ultra 芯片实际上是两个 M1/M2 Max 芯片与硅中介层融合在一起，在融合的芯片之间提供极高速的 I/O。性能并没有完全翻倍， 但也很接近了。假设的四核“Extreme”芯片将有效地将同代 Ultra 芯片的性能提高一倍。这种芯片仅在 Mac Pro 中使用，这将使 Mac Pro 更有明显的理由与 Mac Studio 并存（迄今为止，Mac Studio 已提供 Max 和 Ultra 芯片配置）。

但如果苹果公司在“去年夏天”才取消了四插入式 M 系列芯片的开发工作，并且是针对使用台积电下一代 N3P 工艺的一代芯片，那么这将意味着它将用于 M5 或 M6 一代，不是M4。 2 M4 系列采用 TSMC 的 N3E 工艺制造，除 M4 Max 之外的任何其他变体（计划于明年更新的 Mac Studio 和 Mac Pro）早在今年夏天之前就已经设计好了。

我觉得明年肯定会有 M4 Ultra 芯片，将两颗 M4 Max 芯片的性能融合在一起。或者，也许 M4 Ultra 将采用独立设计，而不是融合两个 Max 芯片。 M 系列 Max 芯片一直是它们自己的设计，而不是两个 Pro 芯片融合在一起。从明年开始，或者从未来的某一代开始，Ultra 芯片也可能出现同样的情况。

但我祈祷我们迟早还会看到“M4 Extreme”——或者苹果决定将其称为“Ultra”之上的级别。然而，如果 The Information 的报道是正确的，要么我们明年会看到四核 M4 芯片，然后它就会跳过一代，因为工程团队被重新定位到这些 AI 服务器芯片上，或者那些工程师正在工作在第一款四最大 M 系列芯片上，现在第一款此类 M 系列芯片已经被押注到更遥远的未来（如果有的话）。可悲的是，今天的报告让我想到，这最快可能需要几年的时间。

  1. 该原文是针对缺少的句子结尾句号的。我希望从400 美元/年的订阅（很快就会涨到 500 美元）中得到更好的文案编辑，每次我访问该网站时，这都会让我升级到 1,000 美元/年的“专业”订阅级别。但是，虽然我对这句话的信息大加指责，但缺少句号是其中最不重要的问题。 “无法了解业务安排的其他细节”是一些被动语态的废话。他们的意思是，马云和刘倩儿无法了解任何额外的细节，而不是苹果和博通之间的业务安排的额外细节是某种不可知的信息——你知道，就像我为什么继续支付这么多钱的答案一样。花钱订阅一份令我烦恼的出版物。 ↩︎

  2. 甚至是M7一代。芯片设计的交付周期以年为复数。早在 2023 年 7 月，就在 M2 代 Mac Studio 型号（提供 M2 Max 和 M2 Ultra）以及第一款（也是迄今为止唯一一款）Apple Silicon Mac Pro (M2 Ultra) 发布后，Jason Snell 和 Myke Hurley以下花絮来自一位匿名听众的播客升级（第 468 集；文字记录）。赫尔利在 4:00 左右在广播中读到了这一消息：

    我是一名 Apple 工程师，在 GPU 团队工作。

    我很痛苦地说杰森的推测是正确的。四核芯片已被封装，没有返回的计划。就背景而言，我们正在积极开发可能是 M5 芯片。而且四芯片只指定用于 M1，并在项目后期被移除。至少到 M7 代还没有创建四芯片的计划。我的理解是，对于太小的市场来说，四核处理器需要付出太多的努力。未来几代 M8 中可能会出现一些有趣的东西，称为多芯片封装。这使得芯片的 CPU 和 GPU 部分可以在不同的芯片上制造并封装在一起，就像两个 max 芯片制造 ultra 一样。通过这种设计，可以想象，我们可以拥有三个、四个、五个或更多 GPU 芯片，以及一个或两个 CPU，用于图形引擎，反之亦然，用于不需要太多 GPU 的 CPU 工作站。但据我所知，目前还没有这样的计划。

    不管你认为对匿名者的评论有多少保留，但它并没有在我耳中引起任何错误的注意。如果这个小升级小鸟是合法的，那就意味着去年夏天以色列芯片工程师从先进的 4× Mac 芯片重新分配到新的 AI 服务器芯片上，他们将一直在 M6 代苹果芯片上工作，用于产品于 2026 年至 2027 年推出。 ↩︎︎

entry.title: 桑伯恩火地图的壮观版式
entry.content:
布兰登·西尔弗曼：

那是 2011 年 9 月，我在 kottke.org 上看到了一个链接，其中包含一小部分令人难以置信的排版，这些排版来自名为“桑伯恩火灾保险地图”的东西。我以前从未见过他们，他们让我大吃一惊。我立即成为了它的忠实粉丝，事实上，当我结婚时，我和我的妻子根据它们设计了我们的婚礼请柬。

然而，从来没有一个地方可以在一处看到地图上的所有艺术作品。到目前为止。

该网站是一个免费档案馆，专门致力于为桑伯恩地图的所有令人难以置信的版式和艺术创建一站式商店。它包括近 3,500 个独特的装饰标题，全部绘制于 1923 年之前。虽然大部分原始地图已数字化并存档在不同地方的线上和线下，但桑伯恩地图中的所有装饰标题从未有过全面收集。我希望你喜欢！

我就是喜欢这种世纪之交的版式和图形设计风格。 （即世纪之交。）在我们这个时代，伟大的克里斯·威尔（Chris Ware）运用这种风格取得了奇妙的效果。

通过，毫不奇怪，科特克。善有善报，恶有恶报。

entry.summary: 如果我想写一篇有关总统赦免的专栏，我会发现 ChatGPT 的帮助是一个比我通过任何一般网络搜索获得的更好的起点。但引用里根的话：“信任，但要核实。”
entry.content:
Elizabeth Lopatto，为 The Verge 撰文，“停止使用生成式人工智能作为搜索引擎”：

现在，人工智能的捍卫者可能会正确地说，一个真正的记者应该检查 ChatGPT 提供的答案；事实核查是我们工作的重要组成部分。我同意，这就是为什么我在这篇文章中引导您完成我自己的检查。但这些只是公开的、令人尴尬的例子，我认为私下里更常发生这样的事情：普通人正在使用 ChatGPT 并信任它提供给他们的信息。

显然是一个错误。

与所谓的答案引擎相比，老式谷歌搜索的一个优势是它直接链接到主要来源。答案引擎只是给你一个答案，而且通常不清楚答案的来源是什么。对我来说，使用 ChatGPT 或 Google 的 AI 功能会带来额外的工作——我必须根据主要来源检查答案；旧的谷歌搜索直接给了我这个来源。

洛帕托的这篇文章是由人们在向生成人工智能系统询问总统赦免家庭成员的历史例子后无意中传播的一系列历史废话引发的。最值得注意的是，查尔斯·皮尔斯 (Charles P. Pierce) 本周在《时尚先生》 (Esquire) 上发表的一篇专栏文章（ 现已完全撤回）的整个前提是乔治·H·W·布什 (George HW Bush) 对其害群之马的儿子尼尔·布什 (Neil Bush)的赦免。没有获得这样的赦免。 1

洛帕托的作品非常出色，尤其是她展示自己作品的方式。她这篇文章的整个前提是，人们实际上是在让自己难堪（在皮尔斯的例子中，非常尴尬），并且通过盲目相信他们从生成人工智能模型中得到的答案，无意中传播了错误信息。但我认为，正如她在标题中所做的那样，断然反对使用生成式人工智能进行研究是错误的。我很晚才将生成人工智能用作好奇心玩具以外的任何东西，但最近几个月我开始将其用于与工作相关的研究。现在我已经开始使用它了，并且越来越多地使用它。我的基本经验法则是，如果我正在寻找文章或网页，我会使用网络搜索（ Kagi ）；不过，如果我正在寻找问题的答案，我会使用 ChatGPT (4o)。我指导（并信任）ChatGPT，就像我指导一名大学实习生担任研究助理一样。我期望准确性，但假设我需要仔细检查所有内容。

以下是我如何提示 ChatGPT，假装我打算写下本周的政治争议：

给我一份美国总统赦免家庭成员、朋友、政府官员和亲信的清单。基本上我正在寻找有争议的赦免名单。我对美国历史的整体感兴趣，尤其是近代历史，比如说过去 100 年。

ChatGPT 4o 的反应很好：这是我的聊天的链接、 HTML 文字记录和屏幕截图。 （只有屏幕截图显示了 ChatGPT 包含来源的位置。）我非常确定 ChatGPT 的回应是完全正确的，而且它让我觉得这是对我一生中最具争议的赦免的公平总结。我最大的争议是它忽略了特朗普对史蒂夫·班农的赦免，这是对一位担任白宫官方顾问的真正渣男的真正令人愤慨的赦免。 （ 班农因一项数百万美元的计划而被起诉，在该计划中，他欺骗了数千名政治捐助者，让他们相信他们正在捐款帮助建造特朗普幻想的“边境墙”。）然而，我问“特朗普还有更多吗？”后续行动产生了一份更长的 13 名赦免名单，全部都是事实，其中包括班农。 2

我想澄清的是，我不认为洛帕托是一个顽固的勒德分子。但今天反对使用生成式人工智能来回答问题的所有论点听起来都与 20 世纪 90 年代反对引用网页作为来源的论点一模一样。当时的论点基本上是“任何人都可以在网络上发布任何内容，即使今天的网页是准确的，它也可以随时更改”——这在当时是正确的，在今天仍然是正确的。 3但它只是一项新技术，不会大行其道，因为它以其他技术无法比拟的方式极其有用，但其固有的缺点将迫使我们适应和学习获取、引用和验证信息的新方法。网络的兴起并没有让图书馆消失。生成式人工智能不会让网络搜索消失。

如果我想写一篇有关总统赦免的专栏，我会发现 ChatGPT 的帮助是一个比我通过任何一般网络搜索获得的更好的起点。但引用里根喜欢的一句格言：“信任，但要核实。”

  1. 洛帕托的这一点值得一提：“我给赫斯特发了一封电子邮件，询问《Esquire》杂志的作家查尔斯·皮尔斯 (Charles P. Pierce) 是否使用 ChatGPT 作为其文章的来源。发言人艾莉森·基恩表示他没有，并且拒绝进一步透露错误是如何发生的。我发现生成人工智能不太可能没有参与布什赦免他儿子的谎言链条中的某个地方，但无论皮尔斯提到什么，他都搞砸了。 ↩︎

  2. 一个小小的好奇是，ChatGPT 的名单虽然大部分是按时间顺序排列的，但却互换了卡特和福特。一个小有趣的是，ChatGPT 为罗纳德·里根提出的唯一据称有争议的赦免是纽约洋基队老板乔治·斯坦布伦纳。老板是一个复杂的人。 ↩︎︎

  3. 谁说狗不能提供有用的信息？ ↩︎︎

大卫·弗鲁姆 (David Frum) 在《大西洋月刊》撰文，谈到他作为 MSNBC 的《早安乔》节目嘉宾时的不和谐表现：

在阅读这篇文章之前，我被问及提名皮特·赫格斯（Pete Hegseth）担任国防部长一事，特别是关于 NBC 新闻的一篇报道，称他酗酒，令福克斯新闻和他领导的退伍军人组织的同事们感到担忧。 [...]我通过提醒观众一些历史来回答：

1989年，乔治·H·W·布什总统提名德克萨斯州参议员约翰·塔尔担任国防部长。塔尔是一个非常重要的人，一个真正的国防知识分子，一个对国防有深刻理解的人，与当前的提名人不同。据了解，塔尔有酗酒问题，当他喝得太多时，他会让自己成为周围女性的麻烦，甚至更糟。出于这个原因，他的提名在 1989 年失败了。你不想认为我们的道德标准已经下降到你可以说：让我们把所有的饮酒、所有的性骚扰，减去任何防御知识，减去任何领导层，都会有你的 21 世纪下一任国防部长。

我用辛辣的语言讲述了这个故事。毕竟这是有线电视。我用一个笑话开始了这次讨论：“如果你喝得太醉而看不到福克斯新闻，那么你确实已经醉得非常非常了。”

在下一个广告时段，一位制片人在我耳边说话。他反对我对福克斯的评论，并警告我不要重复这些评论。我说了一些不置可否的话，又收到了一轮警告。休息结束后，我被问到一个关于另一个主题的后续问题，即关于乔·拜登总统赦免他儿子的问题。我没有回到之前的讨论，不是因为有人警告我，而是因为我已经说了我的观点。然后我被告知我不能坐在工作室的椅子上了。不久之后，联合主持人米卡·布热津斯基宣读了对我言论的道歉。

耶稣。卑鄙的谄媚程度令人震惊。是的，这是福克斯新闻的一个笑话。但福克斯新闻频道（正在播出）确实一直支持赫格塞斯的提名，尽管很明显，在那里工作的每个人都知道他有酗酒问题。 来自 NBC News 的报道（请注意，尽管 MSNBC 和 NBC News 新闻编辑室的名字不同，但它们不再有关联）：

据知情人士透露，虽然这个标题看起来无伤大雅，但黄馨祥对此表示沮丧。标题被允许保持不变。但知情人士称，结果是出台了一项新规则：在发表观点报道之前，必须将头条新闻通过电子邮件发送给 Soon-Shiong，然后他可以选择发表意见。虽然这对于报纸来说是正常现象尽管业主希望影响报纸的舆论部门，但业主在出版前将文章标题发送给他们进行审阅的情况是极不寻常的。

协会为我们的会员提供了强有力的道德保护，包括保留署名的权利，我们将坚决防止任何不正当或不公平地改变我们报告的行为。

entry.title: 谷歌对谷歌消息加密支持的描述感到羞耻
entry.content:
在撰写上一篇有关 FBI 鼓励使用 E2EE 文本和通话协议的文章时，我最终访问了 Google Messages 的 Play 商店页面。关于 Google Messages 对端到端加密的支持，这是可耻的误导。正如我在上一篇文章中所写的那样，Google消息确实支持E2EE，但仅当聊天中的所有参与者都使用Google消息的最新版本时才仅在RCS上。但是， Play商店中的第二个屏幕截图清单列出了“对话是端到端加密的”，全停止。那是一些严重的胡说八道。

我意识到“某些对话是端到端加密的”，自然会对哪些对话进行加密而不是刺激，哪些不是，但这就是事实。该应用程序的用户应该意识到这一点。 “与其他Google消息用户已加密的RCS对话”将有效。

然后，在清单的“报告卡”部分中，它指出以下内容：

数据在传输过程中被加密
您的数据通过安全连接传输

同样，有时只是正确的。以这种方式描述Google消息的过境安全是彻头彻尾的欺诈行为。想象一个没有技术专业知识的典型的Android用户，他接受了建议（现在来自FBI ）来使用端到端加密进行消息传递。一个信任Google的合理人会查看Google对Google消息的描述，并得出结论，如果您使用Google消息，那么您所有的消息都将是安全的。那是假的。并取决于您与谁通信的 - iPhone用户，具有旧设备的Android用户，使用其他文本消息应用程序的Android用户 - 您的大多数消息很可能不会安全。

老实说吧！使用Android手机在Google消息用户之间使用支持RCS的E2EE是完全无缝且自动的（我只是使用Android燃烧器自己尝试过它），但是E2EE永远无法使用SMS，并且如果聊天中的参与者使用任何RCS，则永远不会使用E2EE客户端（在Android或Apple消息上）以外的Google消息。这是一个必不可少的区别，应该明确而不是混淆。

当我这样做时，Google Voice根本不支持RCS也很尴尬。这是Google自己的应用程序和服务，Google一直是RCS消息传递中世界上最声音的支持者。

最后，我还认为Google消息颜色所有RCS消息气泡都具有完全相同的颜色（带有白色文本的深蓝色气泡，natch）是一个坏主意。至少在我的像素4上的SMS消息是淡蓝色，黑色文字。 Google消息确实在时间表中放置了一个小锁，以指示何时RCS聊天安全，并且他们还在发送按钮的纸机飞机图标上放置了一个锁定徽章，因此有视觉上的指示是否加密RCS聊天，但是由于消息是因为消息对于所有RCS聊天，气泡颜色都是相同的，它是微妙的，并不像Apple消息那样明显，绿色的意思是“ SMS或RCS，永不加密”，而Blue表示“ iMessage，始终被加密”。

★

entry.title: 美国官员敦促美国人在中国未加密的电信网络后使用加密的应用程序来发短信和呼叫
entry.content:
凯文·科利尔（Kevin Collier），报道NBC新闻：

在 AT&T 和 Verizon 等电信公司遭受前所未有的网络攻击之际，美国官员建议美国人使用加密消息应用程序，以确保他们的通信不被外国黑客发现。

这次黑客活动被微软称为“盐台风”，是美国历史上最大的情报泄露事件之一，而且尚未得到完全补救。官员们在周二的新闻电话会议上拒绝设定宣布该国电信系统没有入侵者的时间表。官员们告诉 NBC 新闻，中国对 AT&T、Verizon 和 Lumen Technologies 进行了黑客攻击，以监视客户。

华盛顿大使馆发言人没有立即回应置评请求。

不要屏住呼吸。

在周二的电话会议中，两名官员——一位不愿透露姓名的联邦调查局高级官员和网络安全和基础设施安全局网络安全执行助理主任杰夫·格林——都建议向那些希望最大限度地减少可能的美国人使用加密消息应用程序。中国拦截他们的通讯。

“我们的建议，我们在内部告诉人们的内容，在这里并不新鲜：加密是你的朋友，无论是在短信上还是如果你有能力使用加密的语音通信。即使对手能够拦截数据，如果数据被加密，也将变得不可能，”格林说。

联邦调查局称加密为“我们的朋友”似乎是新的，但是现在我想到的，这些年来，他们的牛肉主要是在访问锁定设备，而不是窃听通信协议。他们对设备加密的倡导立场并没有改变 - 他们仍然想要那里的“后门”。我认为，他们的想法是，E2EE通信是一件好事，因为它们可以防止外国对手的偏远窃听 - 就像中国发动的这项运动一样。联邦调查局不需要通过电线拦截通信。当联邦调查局想看到某人的通讯时，他们将获得逮捕他们的设备的逮捕令。这就是FBI想要回门的原因，但现在鼓励使用真正的E2EE协议的使用。但这并不是说全球执法机构仍然不会幻想强制性的“为好人的后门” 。

不过，这是这个NBC新闻故事中的段落的笨拙者：

隐私倡导者长期以来一直主张使用端到端加密应用程序。 Signal 和 WhatsApp 自动在通话和消息中实施端到端加密。 Google Messages 和 iMessage 还可以端到端加密通话和短信。

的确，关于信号和WhatsApp的语音和文本通信总是通过端到端加密来确保。但是Google消息是一个Android应用程序，仅通过SMS和RCS而不是语音处理文本消息传递。 Google消息中有一个“呼叫”按钮，但只需使用电话应用程序拨打联系人 - 只是一个普通的老式未加密的电话。 （在Google消息中有一个视频通话按钮，但是该按钮试图启动Google Meet。）Google消息中的某些文本聊天已加密，但是只有使用RCS的聊天，只有所有参与者都使用Google消息的最新版本。 Google消息确实提供了聊天的加密状态的视觉指标。 RCS标准没有加密； Google消息中的E2EE RCS聊天使用Google的专有扩展名，并且是Google Messages应用的独有的，因此Google消息和其他应用程序之间的RCS聊天（大多数明显的Apple消息）未加密。

iMessage不是应用程序。这是Apple的专有协议，可在其消息应用程序中获得。整个iMessage协议是在端到端加密上构建的 - 从一开始，所有iMessage消息都是E2EE。 Apple还提供语音和视频通话的FaceTime， FaceTime通话总是由E2EE保护。

entry.title: 安迪·格罗夫（Andy Grove）在2000年：“我学到了什么”
entry.content:
安迪·格罗夫（Andy Grove）的一些智慧块在他退休后作为英特尔（Intel）首席执行官后接受采访时，但仍然担任董事长：

利润是企业的命脉。不要让任何人告诉你不同的事情。

您必须了解自己的错误。研究他们的地狱。您将不会有机会再次犯同样的错误 - 您不能在同一地点和同一时间再次进入河流 - 但是您将有机会犯类似的错误。

身份是一件非常危险的事情。我遇到了太多的人，他们是一个自豪的人，他们永远不会从兑现机器中拿走钱，那些太好了，无法拥有自己的电子邮件地址，因为那是对其他所有人而不是他们。很难与诱惑与世界其他地区区分开来。

格罗夫（Grove）在1997年英特尔（Intel）的顶峰期间仍担任首席执行官，甚至没有办公室。 他从一个8x9英尺的小隔间中工作。

您今天看到的是一个非常非常快速的行业发展，在这个行业中，与行业同时长大的人更好地理解了环境。在这段时间之前，我们许多人在业务上花费的很多年仅具有有限的相关性。

这个行业不像其他行业。计算机不会逐渐强大；他们变得更强大。

★
;

想象一下，如果您去看电影，他们为爆米花收费8000美元。

或者，想象一下您上了飞机，他们告诉您安全带仅在头等舱中可用。

当软件供应商以可怕的SSO税击中他们时，您的愤怒不公正感可能会像IT和安全专业人员的感觉。

SSO税是通过将其作为产品的“企业层”的一部分来收取一次性单登录的实践的名称。价格上涨可能会令人惊讶 - 与SSO相比，CRM的收费超过5000％。以这些价格，只有非常大的公司有能力为SSO付费。但是问题是各种规模的公司都需要它。

在一个遭受损害的凭据是违规中排名第一的凭证，SSO减少了弱，重复使用的密码的数量。这对于入职和卸货也至关重要，因为它只需要管理一个/OFF开关，而不是为每个应用程序分别管理访问。

公平地说，向SSO收取额外的费用没有错 - 供应商没有免费建造或维护 - 但是将其脱离了如此多的公司的范围是不负责任的，并且使我们所有人的安全都不那么安全。

尽管如此，在愤怒的客户可以羞辱供应商以摆脱税收之前，许多企业必须弄清楚没有SSO的生活。对于他们来说，最好的路线可能是密码管理器，这也可以减少弱和重复使用的凭据，并可以在整个团队之间进行安全共享。无论如何，密码管理器可能是一项不错的投资，对于未与SSO集成的应用程序。

要了解有关SSO税的过去，现在和未来的更多信息，请阅读完整的博客文章。

entry.content:
Verge的肖恩·霍利斯特（Sean Hollister）在标题“英特尔发生了什么事？不过，这里有一点猫脚在这里引起了我的注意：

基辛格接任最高职位之前情况到底有多糟糕？

不好！经历了错误的赌注、多代芯片的延迟、质量保证问题，然后苹果决定放弃英特尔，转而采用其自主研发的基于 Arm 的芯片——结果证明这是好的，在笔记本电脑性能和电池寿命方面严重展示了英特尔的实力领域。我们在“ 英特尔落后的夏天”中写了所有相关内容。

英特尔早期也曾遭遇过失误：该公司长期以来一直后悔自己没有将英特尔芯片植入 iPhone 的决定，而且它也未能在 Android 手机芯片上执行。可以说，它错过了整个移动革命的机会。

没有关于它的论点。英特尔完全错过了手机。 iPhone从未使用过Intel芯片，而苹果硅芯片都是TSMC的Fabbed。苹果的筹码是行业中最好的，也没有争论，唯一可以看作是合理竞争的移动芯片来自高通公司（也许是三星）。英特尔从来都不是那场比赛的玩家，这是英特尔不仅需要成为一名球员，而且要占主导地位。

不仅是智能手机现在比PC行业更大的行业，而且英特尔错过了成为电话制造商的主导供应商。那很糟糕，但这不是最糟糕的。正是那些基于ARM的移动芯片 - Apple Silicon和高通公司的Snapdragon阵容 - 变得如此出色，以至于他们现在接管了PC市场高端的大范围。部分原因是对每瓦效率的绩效效率的痴迷，部分是由于ARM架构的固有优势，部分是由于工程人才和战略，部分是由于移动市场爆炸时规模经济的深刻益处。众所周知，苹果公司从2020年开始将整个Mac平台从英特尔芯片转移到苹果硅。Mac“仅”拥有15％的全球PC市场，但Mac的全部市场份额是市场。输掉Mac对英特尔来说是巨大的损失。现在， 高通公司和微软也正在将Windows笔记本电脑推向武器芯片，出于同样的原因：不仅是每瓦的性能，而且性能纯粹。 X86 CPU仍然在游戏PC上占主导地位，但即使在那里， AMD也被认为是农作物的奶油。

在所有公司中，英特尔应该已经看到了发生这种情况的可能性。英特尔并没有认真对待“电话芯片”，但是在十年之内，表面上的玩具“电话芯片”是世界上最好的CPU，用于高级PC笔记本电脑，它们的效率优势也使它们在数据中心也有利。苹果表明，它们在工作站级台式机上甚至优越。这正是英特尔在个人计算革命开始时重返英特尔的方式。 1970年代和1980年代初的“真实”计算机制造商将PC视为仅仅是玩具。 IBM被捕获得如此平坦，以至于当他们看到需要进入PC市场的需要时，他们去了Intel进行芯片和Microsoft进行DOS，这是Intel和Microsoft都资本利用的决策，从而导致了标签团队的硬件/软件的优势整个计算机行业持续了整个四分之一世纪，而IBM则被视为另一个PC制造商。从英特尔的角度来看，X86平台从“玩具”到成为廉价笔记本电脑到数据中心级服务器的所有事物的主要建筑。

基于ARM的“电话芯片”对X86做了同样的事情，与几十年前，英特尔的X86“ PC芯片”对大型机做了。同样，NVIDIA将“视频游戏爱好者的图形卡”（也曾经被视为纯粹的玩具）变成了现在的事物，具体取决于股票市场波动，这是世界上最有价值的公司。他们是另一家公司和奈特尔（Intel）的硅设计领导者：苹果公司（Apple）的脖子和脖子。创建“世界上最好的筹码”仍然是一个令人难以置信的，几乎令人难以置信的盈利地点。苹果和Nvidia都可以说，关于其芯片占主导地位的市场群体截然不同。英特尔今天不能说它生产芯片的任何细分市场。 TSMC是Apple Silicon和NVIDIA 大部分领先筹码的所有芯片的公司，在按市值排名的公司名单上排名第9，在英特尔曾经占据的前十名。今天，英特尔是第180名，并且轨迹落在前200名中。

英特尔永远不应该对威胁。该公司的长期首席执行官兼董事长（以及3号员工）安迪·格罗夫（Andy Grove ）的标题只有偏执狂得以幸存。他从中汲取了标题的完整段落：

商业成功包含其自身破坏的种子。成功会滋生自满情绪。自满会导致失败。只有偏执狂才能生存。

格罗夫（Grove）于1998年退休，并于2005年退休，担任董事长。好像他在英特尔（Intel）听过他说的一句话。格罗夫（Grove）的话不仅读为建议 - 他们今天将其作为验尸概要，因为英特尔（Intel）在过去20年中自身急剧下降。

entry.title: ★ 安迪·格罗夫是对的

entry.title: 条纹和小条纹
entry.content:
感谢开发商Quentin Zervaas的公司Crunchy Bagel赞助了本周的DF RSS Feed，以促进条纹，这是它们为iPhone和Apple Watch的出色应用。条纹是一个待办事项清单，可帮助您养成良好的习惯。关键是要激励您解决要做的事情：每日运动目标，学习新语言，服用维生素或戒掉坏习惯的任何事情。任何事物。我从小就每天刷牙，但是我从来没有对牙线刷过 - 直到通常的几天前，预定的牙齿清洁。我最近一直在使用条纹，每天都有牙线习惯。 （我希望下次我在牙医时拍拍。）

Streaks在2016年首次赞助了DF，而我写的所有内容如今仍然如此。从视觉和概念上讲，这都是出色的设计。这些年来，我尝试了一些类似的应用程序，包括近年来的一些新应用程序 - 杀死大多数应用程序是摩擦。如果需要太多的步骤来标记您所做的事情，则停止使用该应用程序。条纹使它变得非常简单，快速地标记完成的事情。对于与活动有关的任何事情，您无需做任何事情 - 它只是自动跟踪HealthKit（当然是您的许可）信息。在视觉设计方面，条纹既具有高度独特又非常iOS-y - 它看起来不像库存的iOS应用程序，但看起来和感觉就像是一个不错的本机iOS应用程序。这是一种组合，需要大量的目光才能实现。 （毫不奇怪，几年前，Streaks获得了Apple Design奖，并且经常在App Store中出现Apple 。）

在过去的8年中，iOS一直没有站着，Zervaas也没有。条纹支持您希望在iOS应用程序（包括Interactive小部件）中获得的所有最新内容。 Streaks的交互式小部件进一步减少了标记事件的摩擦 - 交互式小部件实际上是针对条纹之类的应用程序制造的。 Streaks也有一个很棒的Apple Watch Companion应用程序。

我只接受我为支持的产品或服务的赞助。但是条纹是如此的好，以至于我想（再次）引起人们的注意。我不是用高级赞誉来赞美它，因为这是我的赞助商。我这样做是因为它绝对很好。这是一次一次性的购买，最新的更新添加了季节性主题，正好赶上圣诞节（以及您的新年决议）。

如果您有小孩，请务必尝试一些条纹。这是帮助孩子们专注于例行工作的好方法：用餐时间，睡前，学习骑自行车，刷牙（和牙线！） - 任何事情。一个例程免费的条纹是免费的，或者使用“大胆”的代码在订阅无限常规的第一年享受50％的折扣。

entry.title: “建立LLM可能不会成为一项出色的业务”
entry.content:
卡尔·帕特森（Cal Paterson）：

大型语言模型（LLMS），例如CHAT-GPT和Claude.ai，很寒冷而酷。许多人认为他们将成为未来。也许是 - 但这并不意味着建立它们将是一项有利可图的业务。

在1960年代，航空公司是未来。这就是为什么旧电影中有这么多机场的镜头。但是，航空公司却是不可避免的垃圾业务。我已经乘坐大量破产的航空公司飞行了：君主，哇，托马斯·库克，弗兰德，Zoom。这些都是冠状病毒之前的萧条 - 时代变化，但成为航空公司总是一个坏主意。

这很奇怪，因为其他企业，甚至看起来确实很愚蠢的业务，都更加有利可图。令人惊讶的是，出售碳酸饮料是一项了不起的生意。也许是最好的。在任何一年中，可口可乐的股本回报率很少低于30％。这似乎是非常不公平的，因为成为航空公司是艰苦的工作，但是制作可乐很容易。它更加累人，因为可口可乐实际上并没有使可乐本身 - 外包给“装瓶公司”。他们实际上只是出售它。

这是一篇饼干的文章。清晰，简洁和简单。我发现很难争论。我一再提到一份内部论文，该论文去年从Google泄漏出来，标题为“我们没有护城河，Openai也没有。” Openai游说全球严格的AI监管这一事实表明，他们也担心这一点 -可以通过寻求监管护城河来解释他们对监管的鼓励，因为没有技术或商业模式护城河。

帕特森（Paterson）在与航空业的比较中阐述了他的比较，观察到商业航空公司只有两个供应商：波音和空中客车。他继续：

LLM制造商有时意味着他们的供应商是诸如Amazon Web Services，Google Cloud等这样的云公司。这还不错，因为您可以四处逛逛并让他们竞争削减模型培训的巨大成本。

确实，LLM制造商只有一个真正的供应商：NVIDIA。 Nvidia将所有型号都经过培训的芯片- 无论云供应商如何。这给了NVIDIA巨大的定价能力。与空中客车或波音相比，NVIDIA相对于人类或Openai更强大。

目前，世界上有三家公司的市值超过3万亿美元：苹果，Nvidia和Microsoft。超过2万亿美元的市值只有两个：亚马逊和Google。工程，培训和提供LLMS不是护城河的业务。带有护城河的业务正在制造训练LLM的尖端计算机硬件，该硬件属于Nvidia。

我还有更多关于帕特森的文章的话，但我真的只希望您现在阅读它。

entry.title: John Siracusa's Review of Delicious Library 1.0
entry.content:
John Siracusa, in his inimitable style, reviewed Delicious Library 1.0 upon its release, 20 years ago this month:

Part of what makes the Mac community so special is that so many Mac developers have itches — and, more importantly, corresponding talents — that have little or nothing to do with computers. I invite you to look again at some of the screenshots and artwork in this application. Someone loved those graphics. Someone sweated over every pixel of that application window. Someone knows what it means to be a lover of art, music, books, video games. This is in addition to (not instead of) the ability to write great code.

All of these human facilities and experiences have been harnessed to create not just a mere “program”, “application” or (God forbid) “executable”, but a digital love letter to collectors. Delicious Monster, from its products to its web site , exudes a spirit of passion and fun. “I've never been happier at work”, Wil Shipley told me in an email. “I think it shows in the finished product.”

我也这么认为。 It may only be version 1.0, but it's delicious.

Re-reading this review — which I first linked to, with little comment , upon publication — reminded me of several things. First, Siracusa is one of the few writers I've ever felt competitive with in this racket. This whole thing is so fucking good, and touches upon so many subtle points that are so hard to convey in words. (In some ways it's better to read in its original multi-page layout , via Internet Archive, but those archived versions are inexplicably missing some, but not all, of the screenshots, and for a review of an app as visually ambitious as Delicious Library, the screenshots are essential. But the current Ars Technica version of the review, although it has all the inline images, is missing this “larger version” of Delicious Library's main window . Open the version I'm hosting in a tab for reference. Note too that “larger version” meant something different 20 years ago — it's only 183 KB, but is the largest image in the review.)

Second, I had forgotten just how ambitious Delicious Library 1.0 was, right out of the gate. I remembered that Delicious Library eventually supported barcode scanning via webcams, but that feature was in fact present in version 1.0. It worked incredibly well. And the feature was so far ahead of its time. In 2004, no Mac had yet shipped with a built-in camera . Instead, we all bought Apple's standalone $150 iSight camera , which connected via FireWire. (What a gorgeous device.) By the end of his effusive review, Siracusa (unsurprisingly) has a wishlist of additional features, but what was in Delicious Library 1.0 comprised far more than a “minimal viable product”. It exemplified Apple's — and Steve Jobs's — own ethos of debuting with a bang, right out of the gate. It made you say “Wow!” And then you'd think, “Oh, but it'd be cool if it...” and, it turns out, it did that too.

Delicious indeed.

★
;

entry.title: The End of the Line for Delicious Library
entry.content:
Wil Shipley, on Mastodon:

Amazon has shut off the feed that allowed Delicious Library to look up items, unfortunately limiting the app to what users already have (or enter manually).

I wasn't contacted about this.

I've pulled it from the Mac App Store and shut down the website so nobody accidentally buys a non-functional app.

The end of an era, but it's kind of surprising it was still functional until now. ( Shipley has been a full-time engineer at Apple for three years now.)

It's hard to describe just what a sensation Delicious Library was when it debuted , and how influential it was . Delicious Library was simultaneously very useful, in very practical ways, and obsessed with its exuberant UI in ways that served no purpose other than looking cool as shit. It was an app that demanded to be praised just for the way it looked, but also served a purpose that resonated with many users. For about a decade it seemed as though most popular new apps would be designed like Delicious Library. Then Apple dropped iOS 7 in 2013, and now, no apps look like this. Whatever it is that we, as an industry, have lost in the now decade-long trend of iOS 7-style flat design, Delicious Library epitomized it.

They were even clever and innovative in the ways they promoted the app . The first time Delicious Monster sponsored Daring Fireball for a week, their sponsorship message read, in its entirety:

Organize the shit you like.
Get rid of the shit you don't.
Delicious Library 2.

When they created an iPhone version of Delicious Library, they announced it via this delightfully intricate but decidedly lo-fi stop-motion-animated video .

20 years go by and there's some inevitable nostalgia looking back at any art form. But man, Delicious Library exemplified an era of indie app development that, sadly, is largely over. And make no bones about it: Delicious Library was a creative work of art.

entry.title: OpenAI 可能会开发一个网络浏览器
entry.content:
Erin Woo, Sahil Patel, and Amir Efrati, reporting for The Information (paywalled, alas):

OpenAI is preparing to launch a frontal assault on Google. The ChatGPT owner recently considered developing a web browser that it would combine with its chatbot, and it has separately discussed or struck deals to power search features for travel, food, real estate and retail websites, according to people who have seen prototypes or designs of the products. [...]

Making a web browser could help OpenAI have more control over a primary gateway through which people use the web, as well as further boost ChatGPT, which has more than 300 million weekly users just two years after its launch. It isn't clear how a ChatGPT browser's features would differ from those of other browsers.

In a signal of its interest in a browser, several months ago OpenAI hired Ben Goodger, a founding member of the Chrome team at Google. Another recent hire is Darin Fisher, who worked with Goodger to develop Chrome.

But OpenAI isn't remotely close to launching a browser, multiple people said.

Goodger and Fisher 's hirings weren't secret — both keep up-to-date profiles on LinkedIn — and just because two people have previously created new web browsers (even multiple times) that their new gig is creating a new web browser. But it sure feels like a good guess.

Fisher most recently was at The Browser Company for two years, working on Arc , an innovative browser that I admire for its originality but which simply did not click for me at all. The Browser Company is in flux, too, working both on Arc 2.0 and an as-yet-unnamed second project that might be a more traditional web browser.

Combine this with regulatory pressure on Apple's Safari and especially Google's Chrome, and it's an exciting time for web browsers. It's kind of wild how every few years the web browser market gets shaken up. The pattern that's repeated several times is that just when the browser market seems settled — like the markets for, say, spreadsheets and word processors — there's a period of flux and new entries shake up the market. There was a point when it seemed like Internet Explorer would be dominant forever; today it doesn't even exist. There was a point when Firefox seemed entrenched on Windows; today it's an afterthought . Today Chrome seems entrenched, as dominant as IE once was .也许不是？

entry.title: Apple TV's Hardware Situation Is Fine
entry.content:
Mark Gurman, in his weekly Power On column:

The best scenario for Apple in TV hardware would be a cheap stick (perhaps with no physical remote — use your iPhone instead). It's an idea that Apple marketing executives detest, but it would help the company quickly expand its presence. If consumers want more power and storage, they can opt for the current box.

At the top of the line, Apple could offer something like the new Mac mini, providing the best streaming quality and gaming options. For this exercise, let's call these three tiers the Apple TV SE, Apple TV and Apple TV Max. It would use the same “good, better, best” strategy employed by the iPhone, Mac, iPad, AirPods, Apple Watch and even the Apple Pencil.

Neither of these suggestions makes any sense. The only interesting thing about either idea is trying to decide which one is worse.

Streaming sticks are crap, and Apple doesn't make crap. I also think streaming sticks are fast going the way of the dodo — they were a stopgap low-cost solution for when TV sets didn't have “smart” experiences with built-in integration for major streaming platforms. Those built-in integrations obviate the need for streaming sticks, and Apple TV is now built into TVs from all major brands , including Samsung, Sony, LG, and Vizio. That's the Apple TV app , not the full Apple TV tvOS platform, but that serves Apple's needs. I don't think it's possible to provide a full-fidelity tvOS experience via a stick-sized computer that draws power from an HDMI port, and it's certainly not possible to do so by omitting the goddamn remote control. Arguing that Apple needs to or even ought to build a cheap TV stick today is like those dumb columns from 2009 arguing that Apple needed to make a netbook to compete against shitty $300 laptops. Apple TV is to set top boxes as the Mac is to PCs — it's never going to get a large share of the overall market, but it dominates the high-end of the market catering to people who actually care.

As for Gurman's high-end hardware idea, a Mac Mini starts at $600. What would be the point of connecting such hardware to your TV? A Mac Mini wouldn't offer better streaming quality than the existing Apple TV 4K offers. 4K is 4K, and even older Apple TV hardware streams it perfectly. And while in theory an M4-powered Mac-Mini-caliber Apple TV could offer better gaming than the iPhone-13-era A15 Bionic chip in the current Apple TV 4K hardware, there are zero tvOS games today that target hardware like that, and there'd be little reason for game developers to target such an “Apple TV Pro” device because almost no one would buy one. Whatever the reasons are for gaming not being a big deal on tvOS today, the lack of a “pro” $500 or $600 hardware tier is not one of them.

I think Apple should get the entry price down to $99 (currently $129), and sooner or later they need to update the hardware, if only to support Apple Intelligence. (Perhaps to the A18 or A18 Pro next fall — the current A15 Bionic Apple TV 4K models came out one year after the chip debuted in the iPhones 13 .) But the hardware story for Apple TV is fine.

★

entry.summary: Pondering the future of Pixelmator by looking at the history of Apple's app acquisitions.
entry.content:
My post this week about Shazam's history got me thinking about Apple's track record with acquired apps. Apple acquired Shazam in 2018 , and soon integrated its capabilities into Siri. But they've also kept the Shazam app going, including the Android version . They even still have a standalone Shazam website . I'd say this has been an acquisition that's made everyone happy: existing users still have a great Shazam app, and the core “What song is this?” feature has been made more available and accessible.

At the moment, outside Cupertino ( and Lithuania ) we're left with uncertainty over the future of Pixelmator and Photomator after their announcement of Apple's pending acquisition . In broad strokes, let's consider the strategic reasons Apple might acquire an existing popular app — or in this case, apps.

  • Keep the app going under Apple's ownership — Examples of this include Logic , which Apple acquired by purchasing parent company Emagic in 2002 , and going back even further, FileMaker .

  • Shut down the app and bake the underlying technology into the OS — Examples: Siri and Dark Sky. Siri debuted as a standalone iPhone app in February 2010. Apple purchased the parent company two months later , and Siri appeared as “beta” software built into iOS with the iPhone 4S in fall, at which point Apple pulled the standalone Siri app from the App店铺。 I don't recall Siri, as a standalone app, ever being all that popular. And whatever you think of Siri's quality and utility over the intervening years, it's the sort of thing that makes more sense as a system-level feature than as a standalone app. A lot of people have a lot of wishes for Siri, but I've never seen anyone say “I wish Siri were still just a standalone app.”

    Dark Sky is more complicated. After acquiring it, Apple kept Dark Sky going as a standalone (and cross-platform) app, but only for a transition period. The purpose of the acquisition was to integrate some of Dark Sky's forecasting technology into Apple's own Weather app and the WeatherKit system framework available to third-party apps. Die-hard Dark Sky fans miss it, and some swear that WeatherKit's warnings about imminent precipitation aren't as accurate as Dark Sky's were, but it's hard to argue that Apple did Dark Sky users dirty.

  • Acquihire the developers and designers but scrap the app — This happens in the industry, but not with Apple. I can think of many examples of talented indie developers and designers closing up shop and going to work for Apple, but I can't think of any good examples of a great popular app being shut down for this. The most tragic acquihire I can think of was when Facebook (now Meta) acquired Push Pop Press , an astonishingly talented team that had made a publishing tool for the modern age that might have been the most impressive software I've ever seen in my life 。 And, poof, the whole thing was just shuttered when the Push Pop team joined Facebook. Inside Facebook that same team created Facebook Paper , which espoused many of the principles that made Push Pop's interactive publishing tool remarkable, but Facebook Paper, alas, was not long for this world. Facebook Paper was so good, so forward-thinking, so innovative, that it almost got me to create a Facebook account for the first time.

  • Buy the app out of anti-competitive spite simply to shut it down — The software industry is rife with acquisitions whose only purpose was to quash competition, 1 but I can't recall a single example of Apple doing so. And in the case of Pixelmator and Photomator, it doesn't make any sense — neither competes against anything Apple makes, and they're exclusively available as apps on Apple platforms.

The bottom line is that what we, as users, hope for after a big company acquires a beloved app is for an outcome where the users of that app remain happy. That might mean just keeping the app going, like with Logic. Or it might mean scrapping the standalone app, but bringing the core features of the app into the OS itself, like with Dark Sky. Sometimes it's a mix, though, like with Shazam. Another example like that is Workflow — which began life as a third-party automation utility for iOS, but which Apple acquired in 2017 and turned into Shortcuts . Anyone who liked Workflow surely loves Shortcuts — it's far more powerful and capable as an OS-level technology from Apple than it ever could have hoped to have been as a third-party app.

其他例子：

  • Beats, which Apple acquired for $3 billion in 2014, remains the largest acquisition by price in Apple's history. 2 Beats Music became the foundation for Apple Music.

  • Speaking of music, iTunes began life as SoundJam MP , a third-party MP3 player for the Mac. iTunes was more than just a rebranding — it was a complete redesign and rethinking of SoundJam — but it basically served the same purpose that SoundJam did. (The other option Apple considered was purchasing Panic , whose Audion was SoundJam's arch-rival.)

  • Final Cut was an acquisition — Apple bought it from Macromedia in 1998. But it's a weird one, because Apple purchased it and hired the team before it had even shipped . The acquisition wasn't just the foundation for the Final Cut Pro we know today, but for iMovie too.

  • TestFlight was an acquisition , and like Siri and Workflow/Shortcuts, is the sort of concept that requires being a first-party product to achieve its goals.

  • Shake , a professional video compositing tool, is a rare sad trombone. Apple acquired parent company Nothing Real in 2002, but discontinued Shake in 2009. Some features live on in Final Cut Pro but it does not seem like a successful acquisition for anyone who loved Shake. 3

  • In 2021 Apple purchased Primephonic , and turned it into Apple Music Classical in 2023 . Seems like a complete win for Primephonic fans.

  • Apple made a slew of small acquisitions that have all been funnelled into improving Apple Maps. Eg, Embark , which was a standalone app for transit information and seems to be the foundation for Apple Maps now having good transit features.

It's commonplace in the industry for a large company to acquire a small company that makes a very cool app, and then somehow ruin that app. Sometimes by transmogrifying it beyond recognition, but oftentimes through disinterest or neglect. And Apple is a very large company, and Pixelmator is a small company with two very cool apps. But an examination of Apple's acquisition history doesn't give me any reason for alarm. Apple really does tend to do right by cool app acquisitions.

Apple respects the art of making great apps. Pixelmator in particular is simply too good to scrap, and Apple hasn't made its own bitmap image editing application since, I think, MacPaint. Something like Pixelmator really would slot right in next to Final Cut Pro and Logic Pro as an Apple “pro tool”. Whether they'll keep the name, I don't know, but I think the app will be released under Apple branding as a Photoshop competitor, for Mac and iPad. (Pixelmator for iOS currently runs on both iPads and iPhones, but Apple's own pro tools, Final Cut and Logic, are iPad only.)

I'm less sure if Apple has the appetite to keep Photomator going, to compete directly against Lightroom — a market Apple simply walked away from when they discontinued Aperture 10 years ago. But perhaps they now regret walking away from Aperture. I'm just not sure how close Photomator is to being a credible alternative to Lightroom.

The other path would be to retire both apps and fold the best features and technology (like their ML Super Resolution upsizing) into Photos, and/or into the system-level Core Image framework available to all apps on all of Apple's platforms. I can see how the best of Photomator could make its way into Photos. That's not true for Pixelmator. The acquisition just doesn't make sense to me unless Apple wants to make Pixelmator an Apple-branded pro tool. We'll find out next year.

  1. I still can't fully forgive Adobe for doing this with FreeHand when they acquired Macromedia in 2005 . Macromedia was Adobe's arch-rival in creative design tools, and FreeHand was Illustrator's arch-rival in the vector graphics market. FreeHand made sense to me in a way that Illustrator never did.真是太好了。 ↩︎

  2. The largest acquisition by importance in Apple's history, of course, was their $400 million deal to reunify the company with NeXT at the end of 1996. That's beyond dispute. That was arguably the most impactful acquisition in the entire history of computing. But I'd also argue that it's almost beyond dispute that the acquisition of PA Semi for $278 million in 2008 was far more important than the Beats acquisition. That paved the path for Apple Silicon, an initiative whose importance to Apple's success in the years since would be hard to overstate. ↩︎︎

  3. How's this for an eye-opener on how the market for professional software has changed, quoting from Wikipedia : “Version 2 was released in early 1999 for Windows NT and IRIX, costing $9,900 US per license, or $3,900 for a render-only license. Over the next few years, Shake rapidly became the standard compositing software in the visual effects industry for feature films. In 2002, Apple Computer acquired Nothing Real. A few months later, version 2.5 was released, introducing Mac OS X compatibility. To strengthen the Mac's position in production studios, the Mac version held a price of $4,950 (equivalent to $8,385 in 2023), and users of the non-Mac operating systems were given the offer of doubling the number of licenses at no extra cost by migrating to Mac OS X.” $5,000 a seat as a 50 percent discount! ↩︎︎

entry.summary: My advice to any writer looking to start a new site based on the newsletter model would be to consider Substack *last*, not first.
entry.content:
Anil Dash, “ Don't Call It a Substack ”:

We constrain our imaginations when we subordinate our creations to names owned by fascist tycoons. Imagine the author of a book telling people to “read my Amazon”. A great director trying to promote their film by saying “click on my Max”. That's how much they've pickled your brain when you refer to your own work and your own voice within the context of their walled garden. There is no such thing as “my Substack”, there is only your writing, and a forever fight against the world of pure enshittification.

I am upset by the above, but only insofar as I'm jealous that I had never thought to make the analogy to an author telling people to “read my Amazon”. A publication on Substack is no more “a Substack” than a blog on WordPress is “a WordPress”. It's really quite a nifty — but devious — trick that Substack has pulled to make this parlance a thing.

Substack is, just as a reminder, a political project made by extremists with a goal of normalizing a radical, hateful agenda by co-opting well-intentioned creators' work in service of cross-promoting attacks on the vulnerable. You don't have to take my word for it; Substack's CEO explicitly said they won't ban someone who is explicitly spouting hate, and when confronted with the rampant white supremacist propaganda that they are profiting from on their site, they took down... four of the Nazis.四。 There are countless more now, and they want to use your email newsletter to cross-promote that content and legitimize it. Nobody can ban the hateful content site if your nice little newsletter is on there, too, and your musings for your subscribers are all the cover they need.

I know quite a few people whose opinions I admire who feel the same way as Dash here. I'll disagree. I think Substack sees itself as a publishing tool and platform. They're not here to promote any particular side. It makes no more sense for them to refuse to publish someone for being too right-wing than it would for WordPress or Medium or, say, GitHub or YouTube. Substack, I think, sees itself like that.

你可能不同意。 Like I said, I know a bunch of good, smart people who see Substack like Dash does, and refuse to pay for any publication on Substack's platform because of their “ Hey we're just a neutral publishing platform, not an editor, let alone a censor ” stance. What I can say, personally, is that I read and pay for several publications on Substack, and for the last few weeks I've tried using their iOS app (more on this in a moment), and I've never once seen a whiff of anything even vaguely right-wing, let alone hateful. Not a whiff. If it's there, I never see it. If I never see it, I don't care. 1

What I object to isn't their laissez faire approach to who they allow to publish on their platform, but rather how they present all publications. People do call the publications on Substack “Substacks”. And Substack publications do all look the same, most of them right down to that telltale serif typeface, Spectral , 2 which is kerned so loosely it looks like teeth in need of orthodontia. It's not an ugly font, per se, but it is very distinctive, which contributes, I think significantly, to the blurring of the branding line between Substack publications as discrete standalone independent entities or as mere sections under “Substack” as an umbrella publication.

Substack, very deliberately, has from the get-go tried to have it both ways. They say that publications on their platform are independent voices and brands. But they present them all as parts of Substack. They all look alike, and they all look like “Substack”. I really don't get why any writer trying to establish themselves independently would farm out their own brand this way. It's the illusion of independence.

I absolutely despise that a Substack publication's home page is, typically, nothing more than a sign-up field for your email address to get the publication by email, and a small “No thanks” link to actually read the damn thing. Half the time when I see that page, I just close the tab out of spite. In what world is “No thanks” a good link to convey the meaning “Let me read the thing I came here to read”?

Substack's app , along with the company's home page , defaults to presenting itself as a Twitter-like short-form posting platform. As if what we need right now is another Twitter-like platform. But especially: why would anyone want to participate in a social platform tied to one specific publishing platform? It doesn't make any sense to me, as a reader, nor do I see the appeal to writers on the platform. It only makes sense strategically from Substack's own perspective. If, as a writer, your feedback and social interaction with your audience is tied to Substack's own social graph, your publication is tied to Substack, too. It's so transparently a lock-in play that it's almost hard to object to it. It's right there on the tin. But it's not hard at all to just not use it.

Substack no longer even hosts a majority of the newsletter-style writers I subscribe to. Casey Newton moved Platformer from Substack to Ghost in January. Craig Calcaterra moved his excellent baseball-focused-but-with-heavy-dashes-of-politics-and-pop-culture Cup of Coffee from Substack to Beehiiv in January as well. 3 Molly White runs Citation Needed on Ghost. My newest paid subscription is to CNN expat Oliver Darcy's new media-industry focused Status , for which he chose Beehiiv. And of course there's my friend and Dithering co-host Ben Thompson, whose Stratechery , running on his own platform Passport , not only long predates Substack but served as their model to replicate . (Substack's pitch deck was “Stratechery in a box.”) All of these sites look distinctive, with their own brand. All of them offer much better subscription and delivery management interfaces than Substack.

My advice to any writer looking to start a new site based on the newsletter model would be to consider Substack last , not first. Not because Substack is a Nazi bar, which I don't think it is at all, but simply because there are clearly better options, and the company's long term goal is clearly platform lock-in.

  1. I feel the same way about social media platforms. Are there people I find objectionable on Mastodon, Bluesky, Instagram, and Threads?确实。在 YouTube 上？ Even more definitely.我在乎吗？ No, because I tend never to see their posts, and when one pops up, I can block or mute them, and I never see them again. That's in contrast with X, the former Twitter, where the top replies to many posts are from first class shitbird trolls.我越来越觉得 X 是一个令人不愉快的地方，无法投入我的注意力，所以我去那里的次数越来越少。 I don't eat at restaurants whose food I dislike, and the food at X tastes bad and is only getting worse. ↩︎︎

  2. A free Google font, which says something about Substack. ↩︎︎

  3. Coincidentally, Calcaterra is moving Cup of Coffee from Beehiiv to Ghost this coming week. Mainly out of some frustrations with email delivery reliability at Beehiiv, but also because Ghost seems more flexible. ↩︎︎

entry.summary: I met Dr. Oz ten years ago.
entry.content:
The Hollywood Reporter, which of course is where one now goes to find news of incoming Executive Branch appointments and nominations, “ Trump Nominates Dr. Mehmet Oz to Run Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services ”:

“America is facing a Healthcare Crisis, and there may be no Physician more qualified and capable than Dr. Oz to Make America Healthy Again,” Trump said in a statement. “He is an eminent Physician, Heart Surgeon, Inventor, and World-Class Communicator, who has been at the forefront of healthy living for decades. Dr. Oz will work closely with Robert F. Kennedy Jr. to take on the illness industrial complex, and all the horrible chronic diseases left in its wake.”

He added, “He won nine Daytime Emmy Awards hosting The Dr. Oz Show, where he taught millions of Americans how to make healthier lifestyle choices, and gave a strong voice to the key pillars of the MAHA Movement.”

I met Dr. Oz ten years ago. It was after the Apple event on Tuesday, 9 September 2014, at the Flint Center in Cupertino, where Apple unveiled Apple Watch after introducing the iPhone 6 and 6 Plus. Apple had erected a startlingly large temporary building in front of the Flint Center, which, post-event, was opened to attending media and celebrities to showcase Apple Watch's various capabilities.但是，事后新闻发布会在弗林特中心内举行，位于大型地下礼堂下方的地下房间的拜占庭式综合体中。

I had a one-on-one off-the-record briefing with Jony Ive. (Fascinating and fun — we spent most of the all-too-brief 30 minutes talking about watch bands and the exquisite packaging and charging case of the Edition models.) The waiting area for these press briefings was set up to look a bit like a mostly empty Apple Store. The central focus of this waiting area was a large table with a glass top; under the glass were a variety of Apple Watch models. The table was a prototype of the ones that Apple would put in its retail stores , for which they obtained multiple patents. While I was waiting for my briefing with Ive, the only other person from the media waiting with me was Oz.

It's a weird thing to be alone, effectively, with someone of Oz's celebrity. It's like being in a room with a million dollars in $100 bills stacked in a perfectly-arranged pyramid. No matter how hard you try to direct your attention, your mind keeps popping back to Holy shit, there's a million dollars in cash right there . His hair was perfect, his shirt crisply pressed.这是一件非常漂亮的衬衫。 He smiled at all times, and seemed genuinely happy to be there, and genuinely interested in Apple Watch, but not for what Apple Watch actually was or could be, but simply because it was a major new thing, and he was a VIP invitee at the introduction of this major new thing. And my mind would pop, for the umpteenth time, Holy shit, that's Dr. Oz right there.

We spent an unceasingly awkward 10 minutes circling around that table together. He never shut up. He chattered, nonstop, with inane observations, like “Hey, look at that one, it's orange!那是什么，皮革？” He was not talking to me, nor was he, really, talking to himself. It was like he was talking to a TV camera, as though we were being filmed for B-roll footage for his show — but there was no camera. It was just me and him, standing around that table exhibiting dozens of Apple Watch prototypes that we were unable to touch, with a handful of Apple PR reps hanging around the sides of the room in silence, pecking away on their iPhones, waiting for a notice from one of their colleagues that it was time to escort one of us to our briefing. Oz was called first, thankfully. It gave me a few minutes of silence to gather my thoughts, and study the watches (albeit under glass), without distraction. I sometimes wonder who his briefing was with. (Phil Schiller, perhaps?)

I came away with the impression that Mehmet Oz was, despite his well-deserved medical renown, preternaturally vapid and preening, and, thus, to me, an incongruous figure. Simultaneously a brilliant mind in the field of thoracic surgery, and yet dumb as a rock in everyday human interaction. I spent the first few minutes with him wondering if I should introduce myself. I spent the last few glad I hadn't, because he was so obviously a staggeringly uninteresting and uninterested man.

I would have much preferred spending those 10 minutes chatting with Dr. Nick .
